Before industrial food packaging became common, canning food at home was a way of life.
All these decades later in one small town in Virginia, an almost-forgotten do-it-yourself tradition survives - a community cannery.

But she could not find local versions of the foods that fill her pantry - marinara sauce, applesauce - basically all the food that's preserved in sealed jars and cans.
Canning was life-changing when it was invented.
With heat to kill bacteria and a vacuum sealed lid to prevent contamination, suddenly you could keep food edible for years.
Today cans are everywhere, but the act of canning has vanished inside the walls of huge factories.
